Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violation identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12507
Section Medical, dental and mental health care
Description • (1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent
living receives any needed medical, dental, and mental
health care as required in R 400.12413. Medical, dental,
and mental health care provided must be documented in
the youth's record.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation It is alleged that a youth is not receiving needed medical care.
Investigation This investigation was initiated on 07/31/2025 with a telephone
call to another DHHS Worker. The investigation was conducted
jointly with DHHS Worker. Onsite interviews were conducted on
08/04/2025. They are as follows.
Youth A was interviewed face to face onsite on 08/04/2025.
Youth A is a 17 year old female who resides in the Independent
Living Program (ILP). Youth A reported she recently went for a
ride on a four wheeler with a youth from the agency section of the
house that is for males. Youth A reported they went riding on a
trail in the woods near the facility. Youth A reported when they
stopped on the trail she was bitten by mosquitoes. Youth A
reported the mosquito bites were on her hands, feet, and thighs.
Youth A reported she told program staff about the bites and was
provided with an antibiotic cream. Upon further discussion, Youth
A reported the antibiotic cream was hydro cortisone cream. Youth
A also reported she was given Benadryl to relieve the itching.
Youth A reported she had one tick but pulled it off. Youth A
reported she now uses insect repellent as there also bugs outside
the facility in the yard. Insect bites on her hands and arms were
observed by this consultant and DHHS Worker to be healed with
residual marks.
Youth B was interviewed face to face onsite on 08/04/2025.
Youth B is 16 years old. Youth B reported there are ticks and bugs
in the tall grass beyond the facility yard. Youth B reported staff
help youth if bitten by bugs by providing ice to hold onto the bite.
Youth B reported they have bug repellent to put on when they go
outside as well.
Youth C was interviewed face to face onsite on 08/04/2025.
Youth C is 18 years old. Youth C reported there are mosquitoes
2

and large moths around the facility and yard area. Youth C
reported she and other IL youth have bug spray repellent. Youth C
reported she had one tick bite but pulled the tick off. Youth C
reported staff put calamine lotion on youth who have mosquito
bites.
Chief Administrator was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 08/04/2025. Chief Administrator reported on
07/28/2025, Youth A contacted her by telephone reporting she
had received bug bites while out on a 4-wheeler. Chief
Administrator reported then going to the facility on 07/28/2025 to
view the insect bites reported by Youth A. Chief Administrator
reported when she arrived, Youth A was wearing a tube top and
shorts. Chief Administrator reported she observed the insect bites
and Youth A doesn’t like to wear insect repellent as she does not
like the smell. Chief Administrator reported calamine lotion was
put on Youth A’s insect bites but Youth A refused to take a
Benadryl tablet. Chief Administrator reported she encouraged
Youth A to take a Benadryl tablet which she then did. Chief
Administrator reported later that night, on 07/29/2025, Youth A did
take another Benadryl tablet. Chief Administrator reported on
07/29/2025 Youth A wanted to go to the hospital ER for her insect
bites but that was not needed. Chief Administrator reported by
07/30/2025 Youth A was no longer talking about the insect bites.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via telephone on
08/19/2025. Foster Care Worker reported she is the worker for
Youth A. Foster Care Worker reported she received the concerns
noted in the allegations from Youth A during a telephone
conversation. She had no further information to provide.
Documentation Review:
• Agency Case Notes: A case note dated 07/27/2025,
documents that at 11:35pm Youth A was given calamine
lotion and peroxide for her insect bites.
• A case note dated 07/28/2025, documents Youth A was
given Benadryl at 11:00pm.
• A case note dated 07/29/2025, documents Youth A was
given Benadryl at 10:15pm.
Analysis Youth A reported that she obtained insect bites while on a trail
while four wheeling. Youth A reported that staff gave her hydro
cortisone to put on the bites and she was given Benadryl tablets to
relieve itching. Youth A reports that she now uses insect repellent.
3

Youth B and Youth C reported insect spray is available at the
program and insect bites are treated with ice and calamine lotion
provided by staff.
Chief Administrator reported Youth A’s insect bites were treated
with calamine lotion and Benadryl tablets.
Documentation reviewed indicates staff were providing Youth A
with Benadryl tablets, calamine lotion, and peroxide for treatment
of the insect bites.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206
Section Staff qualifications; volunteer, contractors on central registry
Description • (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and
suitable and able to meet the needs of children and families
served by the agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation It is alleged that staff have food locked up and youth do not have
access to food.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed face to face onsite on 08/04/2025.
She reported staff takes her every Tuesday and Thursday to Wal
Mart to purchase food. Youth A reported she ran out of money as
she is waiting for her bridge card and IL check stiped. Youth A
reported her check was sent to the wrong address and this has
held it up. Youth A reported staff help with food and she and other
youth go to the local food bank and Salvation army. Youth A
reported she and other youth in the program share food. Youth A
reported she has enough food and reports feeling safe at the
program. Youth A denied that staff keep food locked up and not
accessible to youth. Youth A reported she has hygiene products
but wants a certain conditioner for her hair that is not available at
the program.
Youth B was interviewed face to face onsite on 08/04/2025.
She reported she has $292 in food stamps. Youth B reported if
youth get low on food there is food in the house provided by staff.
Youth B reported they get to go to the food pantry every sixty
days. Youth B reported she and the other youth share food. Youth
B reported she brought her hygiene products with her from
4

another program. Youth B denied that staff keep food locked up
and not accessible to youth
Youth C was interviewed face to face onsite on 08/04/2025.
She reported she has a bridge card and is receiving her State
checks. Youth C reported when she runs out of money the staff
provide food. Youth C reported she and the other youth are
learning how to budget for food. Youth C reported she buys her
own food and hygiene products. Youth C reported she and the
other youth share food. Youth C denied that staff keep food locked
up and not accessible to youth.
Chief Administrator was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 08/04/2025. She reported there was a time when
Youth A had food stamps and was low on food after shopping.
Chief Administrator reported Youth A bought a lot of junk food
which is consumed quickly. Staff then took Youth A to the food
bank and Salvation Army and received food from these resources.
Chief Administrator reported the agency provides food twice a
week which is purchased the same day and is not locked. Chief
Administrator reported Youth A, when talking about food locked
up, is referring to other youth and their unwillingness to share with
her. Chief Administrator reported Youth A has never run out of
food. Chief Administrator reported the agency has hygiene
products for youth and Youth A had run out of hygiene “wants”,
not “needs”.
Tour Observation:
- An onsite inspection was completed on 8/4/2025 with
MDHHS Worker. There were no observations of any food
being locked up.
Analysis Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C each reported they have enough
food and when a youth is low on food staff assist in providing food.
Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C report that staff take them food
shopping and they also visit and obtain food from a local food
bank and the Salvation army. Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C
reported they share food among themselves
Chief Administrator reported food is not locked up and kept from
being accessible to youth.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
5

Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12503
Section Policy and procedures
Description • (2) The policies and procedures must cover at least all the
following areas:
• (f) Amount of financial support and how it is
disbursed. An agency may not withhold financial
support intended for the youth while the youth is
actively involved in the program.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation It is alleged that a youth is not receiving her financial supports
checks.
Investigation Chief Administrator was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 08/04/2025. She reported that Youth A’s IL stiped
check was sent to an address at South Central office in Detroit.
The Chief Administrator reported that this is being corrected and
Youth A should receive her check soon.
DHHS Monitor for Youth A was interviewed via telephone on
08/18/2025. The DHHS Monitor confirmed that the stiped check
was sent to the South Central office which resulted in a delay of
Youth A receiving her check. The DHHS Monitor reported that
Youth A has since received her first check with another one soon
to be dispersed. The DHHS Monitor reported that she is
monitoring the dispensing of checks for Youth A.
Youth B and Youth C were interviewed face to face onsite on
08/04/2025. They both reported they receive their checks twice
per month.
Youth A was interviewed via telephone on 8/25/2025. She
stated she has since received two of her checks as well as her
bridge card.
Documentation Reviewed:
- The agency does not have a policy under this rule.
Analysis Chief Administrator and DHHS Monitor each reported Youth A’s
stiped check was sent to the South Central office in Detroit which
created a delay in Youth A receiving her check. DHHS Monitor
reported Youth A has since received her first check. On 8/25/2025
Youth A reported that she has, subsequent to what she reported
in the initial interview, received two IL stipend checks.
6

During the course of the investigation it was determined that the
agency does not have a policy that speaks to the amount of
financial support a youth receives and how it is dispersed.
Conclusion Violation Established.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan the recommendation is for
continuance of the regular license.
